headline: Remembering when Roy Keane rattled Jurgen Klopp with one word about his Liverpool team
body: Roy Keane certainly got a rise out of Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp when the Manchester United legend described the Reds' defending as "sloppy" back four years ago
Roy Keane has never been one to shy away from saying exactly what he thinks, whether that be on the pitch during his Manchester United days or in the studio as a pundit.

However, that doesn't mean the Irishman is free of consequences. Though Keane is a famed hardman who boasts an intimidating aura, not everyone is afraid of giving it back. Just ask Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp, who was certainly aggrieved by one of the United legend's one-word digs aimed at the German's Reds side back in 2020.

Speaking in the aftermath of Liverpool's 3-1 victory over Arsenal, Keane claimed that Klopp's team were "sloppy" in places despite the win. The Reds boss issued a passionate response, having heard what the Sky Sports pundit had said just before his post-match media.

"Did I hear right, Mr Keane said we had a sloppy performance tonight? I could hear you already, did he say that?," Klopp questioned. "This was a sloppy performance tonight? I'm not sure if I heard it right. He may be talking about another game because it cannot be this game. Sorry.

"That's an incredible description of this game, this was absolutely exceptional. Nothing was slopy. Absolutely nothing. From the first second dominant against a team in form, 100 per cent in form. You have to be careful like hell and not get hit by the counter attacks.
"I think 60/70 per cent of all the balls in behind were offside, you just wait a little bit longer for the flag meanwhile, so that's why it feels not great but it was offside.

"Ali [Alisson Becker] had to make one save, there were two balls in behind, you can't avoid that, you need a goal in these situations. Apart from that, the football we played was absolutely exceptional tonight. So it doesn't help for any other game. Not for Thursday, not for Sunday. Not for nothing."

At the time of Keane's assessment, Liverpool's defence was not at its most resolute. Days before the game against the Gunners, Klopp's side shipped three goals at home against now-Championship outfit Leeds United.
Keane did get the chance to reply to Klopp's passionate disagreement with his analysis, telling the Liverpool manager: "I think you must have misheard me.
"I said there were sloppy moments but I think you have been outstanding, I have been giving the club nothing but praise. So I'm not sure you heard me correctly there."

headline: Kobbie Mainoo: Man Utd and England ace has very famous brother who starred on Love Island
body: Manchester United midfielder Kobbie Mainoo has been called up to the England squad and his older brother is now a model and property developer after starring on Love Island
Kobbie Mainoo's rapid rise continued earlier this week after he earned his first England call-up.

The 18-year-old has impressed during his breakthrough season at Manchester United. In fact, the teenager has started in 15 of their last 16 matches despite only making his first Premier League start in November.

Mainoo was initially called up to the England Under 21s squad for the March international break. However, after putting in an excellent performance in United's 4-3 win over Liverpool, Gareth Southgate decided to call Mainoo up to the senior camp ahead of friendlies against Brazil and Belgium this month.

But that is not the only surprise. Fans have been left stunned after discovering that Mainoo has a famous brother, Jordan Mainoo-Hames, who featured on Love Island and has over 700,000 followers on Instagram. Jordan starred on the fifth season of the reality TV show in 2019.

He entered the Mallorca villa during week three and quickly got into a relationship with Anna Vakili. But the couple soon separated after Jordan explored a connection with new arrival India Reynolds. Jordan and Anna were dumped from the island on Day 52 - less than a week before the end of the show.

Since his time on Love Island, Jordan has been a model for Vogue, Louis Vuitton, JD Sports and other well-known brands. As well as that, Jordan has dipped into the property developing industry and has been buying houses in his home city of Manchester before converting them into high-end family homes.

Speaking to Manchester Evening News last June, Jordan said: "I looked at all my favourite high-performance celebrities and tried to figure out what the denominator was between them all achieving success over a long period of time. That denominator was multiple businesses.

" Conor McGregor is a good example. He opened his whiskey business, he’s got McGregor Fast where he does his strength and conditioning. He’s got a pub chain, and what’s he not done for the past three or four years? He hasn’t fought because he’s got all these other businesses that are working hard for him."

One fan said on X, formerly known as Twitter: "Wait is jordan hames actually kobbie mainoo's older brother?!" Another added: "Sorry how am I just finding out that Kobbie Mainoo's brother is Jordan from Love Island?!" A third continued: "Jordan from Love Island is Mainoo's brother???"

United midfielder Mainoo will be hoping to impress if he is handed his first England cap against Brazil on Saturday or Belgium next Tuesday. The Three Lions are among the favourites to win Euro 2024 this summer, with Southgate's side facing Serbia, Denmark and Slovenia in their group.

headline: Man Utd news: Harry Maguire makes Gareth Southgate admission as £43m signing eyed
body: England manager Gareth Southgate has emerged as a target for Manchester United, while Juventus defender Gleison Bremer is also said to be on the Red Devils' radar
Manchester United are planning for the future with new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe now in charge of the sporting side of the business.

Erik ten Hag has struggled to build on a promising first season in charge and it remains to be seen whether he will still be the manager next season. United are still in with a chance of qualifying for the Champions League and an FA Cup final appearance beckons.
They beat rivals Liverpool 4-3 in extra-time last weekend to set up a semi-final clash against Championship side Coventry next month. With all that in mind, here's the latest from Old Trafford.
Harry Maguire wants Gareth Southgate to remain in charge of England beyond Euro 2024, despite Ratcliffe making him his top target to replace Erik ten Hag as United boss this summer.

When asked if he wants Southgate to stay with England, Maguire said: "Yeah, definitely, obviously.‌ We want to be successful in the Euros – we are not looking at the World Cup at the moment – but obviously, if we are successful at the Euros, which is our main focus, of course, we want to be successful.

"If Gareth's the man to make us be successful then we want him to stay as long as possible. ‌I don't know what's going to happen after the Euros, I don't know if he knows what's going to happen. But I feel like what he's done from when he first took over this job to where we are at now, we've taken huge strides and he's a massive part of that."

Juventus defender Gleison Bremer has emerged as a transfer target for United, according to reports from Italy. It is claimed that Dan Ashworth, who is close to becoming United's new sporting director has endorsed a move for Bremer. The centre-back is said to have a £43million release clause in his contract.

Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite has also been linked with a summer switch to Old Trafford, having earned England recognition after impressing for the Toffees following a loan spell at Dutch club PSV Eindhoven last season.

Christian Eriksen has been backed by teammate Rasmus Hojlund after admitting he is unhappy with his recent lack of game time. "I have had a conversation with Erik about being unhappy with the situation and wanting to play as much as possible, but I am available and need to be available for the team, which I am and always will be," Eriksen told Tipsbladet while away on international duty with Denmark.

And when asked about Eriksen's comments, Hojlund told TV2: "I myself have sat on the bench for FC Copenhagen, so I know what that means. But he holds his head high and he is a class player. He trains well and is still very positive and very helpful, so it's not a big deal."

headline: Man Utd's four back-up options to replace Erik ten Hag after Gareth Southgate's admission
body: Manchester United could yet change their manager next season but, after England boss Gareth Southgate spoke out, the Old Trafford bosses may have to look elsewhere
Manchester United could be on the lookout for a new manager next season amid uncertainty over the future of Erik ten Hag.

The Dutchman is in the midst of his second season at Old Trafford but has failed to build on a promising opening campaign. The Red Devils face the prospect of missing out on the Champions League and Sir Jim Ratcliffe has now come on board to take control of the footballing operations.

As a result Ten Hag's future remains unclear and Gareth Southgate was earmarked as the club's top target. Since those reports emerged the England boss, whose own future at Wembley is unknown beyond the Euros, has distanced himself from the dugout in Manchester.

He said: “There are two things from my point of view. One is I'm the England manager. I've got one job basically, to try to deliver a European Championship and the second thing is Manchester United have a manager. I think it is always completely disrespectful when there is a manager in place. I don't have any time for that sort of thing."

It could leave Ratcliffe and United look elsewhere as they aim to take the club forward and make them consistent challengers once again. The Red Devils have won just one trophy since 2017 but several highly thought of tacticians could be the man to take United back to the top. Here's several options Ratcliffe could consider.

The ex-Chelsea boss was previously linked with the Old Trafford hotseat and will be a man without a job come the summer as he's leaving Bayern Munich. Tuchel has proved he can be competitive in England and whilst in charge of the Blues claimed the Champions League back in 2021.

The only concern for Ratcliffe and co may be Tuchel's relatively short periods in his various jobs - he lasted around two years or less at PSG, Chelsea and Bayern. He has shown himself to be a serial winner however and would demand the respect of the dressing room and bring with him a clear style.

Whilst the Brighton boss continues to be linked with the soon to be vacant Liverpool job United could yet swoop in. It would be something of a risky move given the club, with the exception of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, have employed proven managers over the past decade or so.

David Moyes was the last man who managed a Premier League club outside the top six and was then hired by United - and that lasted less than a year. De Zerbi though is one of the most sought after young managers in Europe and has impressed with the Seagulls, causing major problems for top sides.

Zizou has been out of a job since leaving Real Madrid for a second time and had his eyes on the France national job until recently and will likely have to consider another club role if he's keen on a return to the dugout. His CV is an impressive read having led Los Blancos to a hat-trick of European Cups.

His tactical IQ has by no means been lauded, but Zidane's greatest strength is being able to get the best out of big name players, who want to play for him. Managing the dressing room would be no issue and the French great would no doubt attract big names.

Another of Europe's exciting young managers but, unlike De Zerbi, Amorim has silverware to back-up his talent. The Sporting Lisbon boss just missed out on crossing paths with Bruno Fernandes, but since taking charge in the Portuguese capital he's won two domestic cups and the league once - and could yet make that twice in the coming months.

Sporting are well set with Amorim the only man to consistently upset the duopoly of Porto and Benfica. Amorim was linked with the United hotseat when they eventually opted for Ten Hag but, two years on, he and the Red Devils could see a union that would have serious longevity to it.

headline: Gareth Southgate breaks silence on Man Utd links and makes pointed Erik ten Hag admission
body: England boss Gareth Southgate has been installed as Sir Jim Ratcliffe's favourite to replace Erik ten Hag at Manchester United and he has now given his take on a potential move to Old Trafford
Gareth Southgate has ruled himself out of the running to be Manchester United boss this summer.

Southgate committed himself to the England job and said he would refuse to have discussions with any club until after the Euros. That effectively means that United would have to wait until mid-July to get Southgate who also branded the talk “disrespectful” to Erik ten Hag.
United have made Southgate their No1 target should they axe ten Hag but the England manager’s comments were designed to defuse the issue so he can concentrate leading the nation to glory this summer.

Southgate, talking on the eve of the Wembley friendly with Brazil, said: “I’m certainly not going to speak to anyone else, I never have, I’ve been eight years in the job and would never entertain speaking to anyone else while I’m in a job, so I don’t know if that answers your question.
“My focus is the European Championship. If we did a contract here before then everybody would be saying: ‘Why are you signing a contract before a Euros where you’ve got to prove yourself?’”

Southgate also underlined his commitment to the “manager’s code” in not wanting to go behind ten Hag’s back while the Dutchman is still in a job at Old Trafford. It actually means that Southgate’s best chance of getting the United job would be for them to stick with ten Hag for the start of next season - and then make a change into the campaign.

Southgate added: “There are two things from my point of view. Firstly, I am the England manager and I have got one job, basically, to try and deliver a European championship. Clearly, before that, two important games this week.

“And the second thing is Manchester United have a manager. I think it is always completely disrespectful when there is any speculation about a manager who is in place. I am president of the LMA so I don’t have any time for that sort of thing.”

The Football Association are desperate to get Southgate to sign a new contract beyond his current £3m-a-year deal which expires in December. But Southgate insists that he will put all talks about his future on the back burner until after the Euros, although he may decide he wants another crack at a World Cup but would only quit England for a big club job.

headline: opinionMan Utd should think twice about hiring Gareth Southgate - they don't need a master of near-misses
body: Gareth Southgate’s England reign has been positive on the whole - but after three major tournaments on his watch, it has also been a tale of missed opportunities
Gareth Southgate may be the most successful England coach since Sir Alf Ramsey - but is he ruthless enough to be manager of Manchester United?

The England job comes with harsh scrutiny, but in terms of global attention United is a worldwide institution where the pressure is unrelenting 24/7 and 52 weeks a year. To my mind, Southgate’s England reign has been positive on the whole - but after three major tournaments on his watch, it has also been a tale of missed opportunities.

And Manchester United aren’t in the market for missed opportunities - they have had a decade of those since Sir Alex Ferguson retired. First things first: Erik ten Hag is still in charge at Old Trafford, and if he goes on to win the FA Cup and finish in the top four, there is a difficult conversation to be had about him staying on.

Whatever happens in future, United fans will always savour the memory of that comeback against Liverpool in the FA Cup quarter-finals. But Ten Hag knows how football works. There is no smoke without fire, and clearly Southgate has his admirers in co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s football operation.

He is a decent, principled man who would wear the United blazer with pride and distinction. But would he deliver results where they matter most - on the pitch? Southgate has had a golden generation of players at his disposal with England, but so far he has missed the boat when the big prizes were there for the taking.

In 2018, England were 1-0 up against Croatia in a World Cup semi-final but failed to press home their advantage. In the Euro 2020 final against Italy, they were 1-0 up again but lost on penalties - on home soil and against a side who failed to qualify for the next World Cup.

And in Qatar 16 months ago, England were knocked out by France in the quarter-finals despite nullifying Kylian Mbappe. People talk about Harry Kane’s missed penalty, but that was another fantastic opportunity to go on and win a major tournament.

United don’t need a manager who is a master of near-misses. They need a winner. Sure, he would enjoy the support of players like Harry Maguire, to whom he has shown great loyalty at international level.

But is Southgate ruthless enough to build an empire like Fergie or Sir Matt Busby? If he was offered the job, and he took it, he would have to hit the ground running because, in the eyes of some fans, it would be an underwhelming appointment.
I like Gareth Southgate as a person. He is a nice guy - but nice guys in football don’t often bring home the trophies.

headline: Man Utd could take advantage of latest Premier League FFP charge in transfer window
body: Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall has been linked with a move to Manchester United this summer as Leicester face potentially selling their star man after being charged by the Premier League
Manchester United could benefit from the latest set of Premier League charges with a potential move for Leicester midfielder Kieran Dewsbury-Hall.

The 25-year-old has been a standout performer in the Championship this season with Leicester eyeing an instant return to the top-flight. Enzo Maresca's side were in a commanding position and clear at the summit, but a run of one win across their last five matches has seen the chasing pack close in.

Now, Leicester have been hit with a Premier League charge. It was confirmed on Thursday that the Foxes have been referred to an independent commission for allegedly breaching profit and sustainability regulations. They have also been accused of failing to submit their accounts to the top-flight on time.

The Foxes could face a points deduction at the start of next season if they are promoted and found to have breached regulations. Leicester issued a furious statement saying they are "surprised" by the actions and will "defend itself from any unlawful acts by the football authorities."
But Leicester might be forced to sell players, even if they are promoted. This is where United could take advantage as the club are reportedly interested in signing Dewsbury-Hall.

Brighton wanted to sign Dewsbury-Hall in January and supposedly had a £20million bid rejected by Leicester, who were asking for an offer in the region of £45m. If the Foxes are promoted, it's said that they will want around £40m - the same fee Tottenham paid to sign James Maddison last summer.

But should the Foxes stay in the Championship, then the asking price for Dewsbury-Hall could drop to as low as £25m, which could prove to be a bargain. The Shepshed-born midfielder has scored 10 goals and provided 12 assists in 36 Championship appearances this season and has three years left on his contract.

Amid the noise surrounding his future in January, Leicester boss Maresca told The Telegraph that Dewsbury-Hall informed him that he wanted to stay at the King Power Stadium. He said: "Kiernan came to me when there was all the noise about him and told me that he had no intention of leaving the club.

"He said he had an obligation to get Leicester promoted. He feels responsible for last season and wants to take the club back to the Premier League. All the other players are the same. Pride is important and they want to be back where they've been for so many years. I love having that commitment from them."

headline: Man Utd star admits he's sad at how things have gone since agent took aim at Erik ten Hag
body: Manchester United winger Facundo Pellistri has spent the last month-and-a-half on loan with Granada in Spain, but he has been left disappointed by the La Liga outfit's current woes
Manchester United winger Facundo Pellistri is unhappy with how his loan spell at Granada has gone as the La Liga outfit edges closer to relegation.

The Uruguay international, 22, hardly featured during the first half of the season for the Red Devils and, as a result, was the subject of transfer interest in January. United sanctioned a six-month loan move to Granada late in the winter window to allow Pellistri to continue his development.
Unfortunately for the youngster, his time in Spain has been somewhat of a mixed bag. While he has played plenty of football, Granada parted company with manager Alexander Medina this month.

And the outlook is pretty bleak when it comes to relegation, too. Jose Ramon Sandoval has been drafted in to replace Medina, but Granada are second from bottom in La Liga and 13 points from safety as we head into the final weeks of the season.

Speaking to AUF TV, as quoted by ESPN, Pellistri expressed his disappointment with the club's current plight, saying: “At the club we are going through a complicated time, but football is like that, there are good and bad moment and you have to be quick to change the chip and bring good energy here. When I return to the club, we have to continue with the best of energy to achieve our objectives, and try to do our best here.”

He added: “I’m getting a lot of minutes in Granada. I’m happy about that part, but sad about how the level of the group is going, we all want to achieve the objective the objective, there are still chances: as long as those chances are there, we’re going to keep fighting.”

Pellistri's latest comments come months after his agent, Edgardo Lasalvia, took aim at Erik ten Hag. He appeared to suggest that it would be "difficult" for his client to continue at Old Trafford if the Dutchman remained in charge as a result of his limited game time.

Lasalvia told Sport 890 earlier this year: “Whether he returns to Manchester in the middle of the year will depend on the performance he shows. If Ten Hag continues, it’s going to be difficult. Ten Hag hasn’t used him, valued him, or treated him like a professional.”

Pellistri adopted a more conservative approach when he was asked about his long-term future earlier this month but also made it clear he would keep his options open heading into the summer. He has featured just 24 times in total for Manchester United since signing for the club from Penarol back in 2020.

headline: Alejandro Garnacho and two Man Utd team-mates spotted mocking Premier League rival
body: Douglas Luiz angered Man United players with his celebration after equalising for Aston Villa and his antics have not yet been forgotten by Alejandro Garnacho and team-mates
Six weeks on, Manchester United's players have still not forgotten Douglas Luiz's celebration in front of goalkeeper Andre Onana and Raphael Varane.

The Brazilian's shimmy after scoring for Aston Villa in the mirror.co.uk/all-about/premier-league>Premier League game that ended with United earning a late 2-1 win was described as "disrespectful" afterwards.
And Alejandro Garnacho was replicating it in front of the cameras during a training session earlier this week in a perceived dig at the Villa star.
In a video posted on social media by United, winger Garnacho, behind coach Darren Fletcher, was seen dropping to his knees at the end of a drill before shaking his shoulders.
And in the background Amad Diallo, the hero of last weekend's FA Cup quarter-final win over Liverpool, and Willy Kambwala soon copy Garnacho by dropping down to carry out the same celebration.
Varane confronted Douglas Luiz after Scott McTominay's winning goal, celebrating in the Villa player's face in an act of sweet revenge.

And United head coach Erik ten Hag was quizzed on Douglas Luiz's celebration in his post-match press conference. He admitted it may have motivated his players to win the match, saying: "I don't have an opinion on it.

"I haven't spoken to the players. It may have fuelled the players. I don't know. We have to think about our game. Not about the opposition. We always want to control the game and dictate it. That should be our approach."

Douglas Luiz was also involved in an altercation with Rasmus Hojlund as the Denmark international left the pitch in the final couple of minutes. The United striker, who scored the opening goal, was in no rush to leave the pitch after being substituted and that incensed Douglas Luiz, who went over to grab his opponent and usher him off.

Unai Emery's Villa remain in fourth place, nine points clear of United but with an extra game played. Fifth is likely to be good enough for a Champions League finish this season thanks to England’s high UEFA co-efficient.

But that place is presently occupied by Tottenham Hotspur, with Ten Hag's men six points behind. Garnacho is among those who have remained at United during the international break and they return to action on Saturday, March 30 with a trip to Brentford and a game that kicks off at the uncomfortable time of 8pm.

headline: Man City fan vandalised Man Utd supporting neighbour's fence with vile Munich jibe after row
body: Michael Hatton, 63, became involved in a bitter feud with his neighbours in the Hollins area of Oldham, Greater Manchester, and daubed the fence with a vile slur
A Manchester City fan daubed a vile slur about the Munich Air Disaster on his neighbours' fence after discovering they were United supporters, a court has heard.

Michael Hatton, 63, got into a bitter argument with his neighbours - a man and his girlfriend - in the Hollins area of Oldham over a wooden fence he had erected between their front gardens, the court was told.

As the dispute heated up, Hatton painted '58' - a cruel reference to the 1958 Munich air crash which claimed the lives of 23 people, including eight members of the United squad - onto the fence. It was also said that he daubed the words 'City rule OK, 'United are s***' and 'f*** off' with paint.

In another incident, when the couple were accused of playing loud music late at night, Hatton, who works as a painter and decorator and lives with his wife, used his electric drill at 5.45am the next morning to attach 27 screws to the fence. He shouted: "You are going to get this every morning you f****** scum."

Tameside Magistrates' Court was told that Hatton was also heard shouting 'sl**' and 'I hope that lady dies' when the couple had their grandchildren over for a visit. In a statement, the male victim, who is currently selling his house, said he and his partner felt like they had been forced to 'live in hell'.

He said: "Michael has caused us to live in hell for the last four years. We are terrified of it escalating. We have never retaliated. We desperately want to move so that we do not have to live in fear.", reports the Manchester Evening News.

"He wrote offensive remarks which obviously put people off purchasing the house. We are worried about the children getting hurt. We feel that this will only end once we have moved. He is fixated on causing us issues and harassing us."

The male's partner said: "I absolutely hate living here because of him. We have been forced to put the house up for sale to move away. He frightens me because of the kids. I tell my family to be vigilant when going out in the dark in case Michael does something.

"I cannot sit in the garden with my granddaughter. I worry he might throw something over the fence and hurt her. He is violent and aggressive. He genuinely frightens us and makes us feel paranoid. I am constantly checking the garden to see if there is any damage he may have caused overnight. We are living in fear. He has made our life here hell in a short space of time.
Suchitra Goswami, prosecuting, said: "This is a matter involving a neighbour dispute where the defendant has been harassing the neighbours. This started in 2020.

"The victims have complained that the neighbour, the defendant, damaged a fence post which separated the garden between the two addresses. One of the victims states that the damage was done deliberately.

"Before the damage the defendant had installed new fencing on his land. On February 16, the complainant overhears the defendant outside of the rear property saying to another neighbour ‘I hope that lady dies.’

"She also overhears the defendant calling her daughter a 'sl**'. On May 30, the defendant used his drill in the early hours at 5.45 to 6.45 stating ‘you are going to get this every morning you f*****g scum.’
"On June 4, approximately 27 screws were found in the fence between the neighbours’ properties. The screws were approximately 1.5 inches long. There was no reason for those to be put there.

"For another incident on May 20, the complainant states that they returned home to find offensive writing written on the fence, visible on their side of the garden. The defendant is aware that the victims are Manchester United fans where the defendant is a Manchester City fan.

"On the fence he wrote, ‘City rule OK. United are s*** and f*** off' and ‘58’. He states that the 58 was a reference to the 1958 Munich air disaster involving a number of United players who died. This was prolonged period of causing maximum distress to the victims. They have clearly suffered."

The court heard that Hatton has a history of 14 offences, including battery. His lawyer, Mohamed Patel insisted tensions between the neighbours have since 'settled down'. Mr Patel said: "It is a sad situation. Ordinarily one would expect neighbours to live well together. Initially they were living well together and helping each other out.

"But the issues began in 2020 when the gentleman found a new relationship with his current partner and relationship between the neighbours got a bit sour. Music started being played a bit loud and that saw the relationship going into a downfall.
"It is always difficult with neighbour disputes. Each party thinks that they are in the right but he fully accepts responsibility for this offence.

"While I accept it is an ongoing dispute which goes back to 2020, this offence dates from 2023. There have been no further offences since June 2023, no further reports from either party to police. There have been no further issues. I would submit that things have settled down between the two neighbours."

Mr Patel said Hatton was upset because his neighbour took down some old fencing after he put up new posts, and he reacted to their loud music, He explained: "In relation to the drilling the night before the neighbours were playing loud music and it was a reaction to that.

"He fully accepts that he should not have done this. There have been no further developments or further issues. I understand that the neighbours’ house has been sold. It is just a matter of time before they move out."
Hatton pleaded guilty of causing trouble between Feb 15 and June 4 of last year. He got a six-month community punishment with 15 days of special activities with the probation service.
He also had to pay £100 as fine, as well as £199 in charges. Also, a restraining order for two years was put in place, stopping Hatton from going near his neighbours or stepping onto their property.

headline: FA Cup semi-final dates and kick-off times announced as Man Utd vs Coventry moved forward
body: Manchester United's FA Cup semi-final match against Championship side Coventry City has been moved forward by the FA after a request made by the Metropolitan Police
The semi-finals of the FA Cup are set to take place at Wembley next month and Manchester United's clash with Coventry City has been brought forward due to concerns from the Metropolitan Police.

In the first semi-final, Manchester City will face Chelsea at 5.15pm on Saturday, April 20 before United take on Coventry at 3.30pm the following day. The Football Association (FA) are said to have requested a 4pm kick-off, but they have now agreed to move the match after talks with police.

According to the Daily Mail, the match was viewed as 'high-risk' by the police, with the FA and broadcasters said to have been left frustrated about the change as later kick-offs typically mean larger TV audiences.

City are the defending champions, having beaten United 2-1 in the final last year as they completed a historic treble, and Pep Guardiola's side will enter their semi-final against Chelsea as the favourites.

United, meanwhile, will be favourites to win the other semi-final after winning a dramatic quarter-final clash with Liverpool 4-3 in extra-time. Championship side Coventry, however, have the potential to cause an upset after they beat Wolves 3-2 to book their place at Wembley

And Coventry boss Mark Robins, who won the FA Cup as a player with United in 1990, is very much looking forward to facing his former club. "I honestly think that the teams that are left are just top, top sides, but my preference was United," he told Coventry Live.

"At one point it looked like Liverpool were going to go through but then it just turned on its head. Obviously, I wanted United to win the game and then we got drawn out first and they followed us out, so perfect!

"But it would be a great game whichever team you pull out. They have got top players and individuals but it’s a game we can look forward to. It's a Wembley trip and it's brilliant for the supporters, the players and the staff and everyone involved, and we can go and have a go at Wembley against a top team with a top manager.

"They'll be expected to win, 100 per cent, and we want to try and go and give a really good account of ourselves again, and enjoy it. At the end of the day, it's a fantastic achievement just to get to this stage but it's one of those things where you don't want to just go and make up the numbers."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund backs unhappy Man Utd star after private talks with Erik ten Hag
body: Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund has sent a message of support to Christian Eriksen after the playmaker revealed he has held talks with Erik ten Hag over his recent lack of action
Rasmus Hojlund has sympathised with Christian Eriksen after the Manchester United midfielder expressed his frustration over a lack of game time.
Eriksen, 32, has fallen down the pecking order following the emergence of the prodigious Kobbie Mainoo and has been forced to settle for a place on the bench in recent weeks.

The Denmark international has featured for just 37 minutes across United's last seven league matches and was benched again for last weekend's epic FA Cup triumph over Liverpool, appearing only as a late substitute.

The veteran midfielder is currently away on international duty but revealed he has spoken to Erik ten Hag over his concerns, explaining to Tipsbladet: "I have had a conversation with Erik about being unhappy with the situation and wanting to play as much as possible, but I am available and need to be available for the team, which I am and always will be.

“He said it was the team he had chosen, and Kobbie is doing well and the rest of the midfield is also performing well, so there is competition for places, which is expected when playing for a top club. There is great competition within the team.
While Eriksen has stressed that the current situation is not "keeping him up at night", his United team-mate and compatriot, Hojlund, has sent his support to the playmaker.

The 21-year-old striker has drawn on his own experiences, telling TV2: “I myself have sat on the bench for FC Copenhagen, so I know what that means. But he holds his head high and he is a class player. There is absolutely no doubt about that.

“There is no concern at all from me about it. Of course, you want to play football. And I’m sure he does too. [But] he trains well and is still very positive and very helpful, so it’s not a big deal. [Eriksen is] a real professional."
Mainoo's emergence has also impacted Casemiro's standing at Old Trafford. Like Eriksen, Casemiro has played significantly less this season, although he's also been plagued by injuries.

It's expected that the veteran midfielder will be one of the players made available for transfer this summer. Mirror Football revealed on Thursday that Wolves' holding midfielder Joao Gomes has been identified by Ineos as a long-term replacement for Casemiro if United can find a buyer for him in the summer transfer window.

headline: Man Utd prepare £43m offer for defender as Dan Ashworth's first transfer assignment emerges
body: Manchester United are already making plans behind the scenes ahead of the summer transfer window ahead of the arrival of Dan Ashworth, who is currently on gardening leave
Manchester United are ready to firm up their interest in Gielson Bremer ahead of the arrival of the club's prospective new sporting director, Dan Ashworth.

It's anticipated that the Red Devils will be busy this summer following several structural changes. Ineos chief Sir Jim Ratcliffe is now at the helm after acquiring a minority stake in the club and has already made his mark behind the scenes.

It's widely been reported that one of the 71-year-old's most pressing priorities was the appointment of a new sporting director and Ashworth, who has impressed in roles with Newcastle, Brighton and The Football Association, has emerged as a primary target.
He's currently on gardening leave while United attempt to agree a financial package for his services, but summer recruitment plans are starting to take shape in the meantime.

United are keen to bolster their defence in the summer window and Bremer is on the club's radar after impressing at Juventus. While Ashworth will be tasked with overseeing the club's recruitment strategy and will have a deciding say in transfer matters, it's been claimed by reports overseas that he has endorsed Bremer, although this is unconfirmed.

It's previously been reported that Bremer has a £43million release clause in his contract; a sum which is unlikely to be viewed as excessive. Ratcliffe has already expressed a desire to move away from the habit of spending huge amounts of money on ageing players.

Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite is also on United's radar following a string of impressive performances for the Premier League strugglers this term. At just 21 years of age, he fits the profile of perspective signings United want to pursue, although he would likely command an extremely high transfer fee.

With United open to signing two new centre-backs in the summer, departures are also expected. Raphael Varane is due to be a free agent at the end of the season and, barring a late change of heart is likely to leave the club.

The former Real Madrid defender made a big impression after signing for United in the summer of 2021 but has fallen down the pecking order under Erik ten Hag this term, with the Dutchman instead handing an olive branch to former captain Harry Maguire.

It's broadly anticipated that several other high-earners are likely to be made available for transfer at the end of the season too, meaning the likes of Casemiro and Antony could join Varane out the exit door.

headline: Man Utd star dubbed "massive problem" 'dreams of playing for Real Madrid'
body: Manchester United are set to see one of their brightest young stars become the subject of a major transfer chase from Real Madrid as the Spanish giants continue their rebuild
Alejandro Garnacho has emerged as a target for Real Madrid - just days after Ian Wright labelled him a "massive problem" for opposition teams.

Garnacho has starred for the Red Devils since Erik ten Hag took charge, earning a five-year contract last April. So far this season he has scored seven goals and notched four assists in all competitions.

His performances have also seen him called up to the Argentina squad for their friendlies against El Salvador and Costa Rica this month. The winger is also in line to play a key role in their Copa America campaign this summer.

But those very performances have also begun to draw the interest of rival teams. Madrid in particular are eyeing a move for the 19-year-old, with Los Blancos continuing to reshape their squad for a new era.

Reports from Spain earlier this week claimed that club president Florentino Perez is keen to sign Garnacho. Perez is set to meet with the United star when Madrid face Manchester City in the Champions League next month.

Such an approach is likely to be welcomed by Garnacho, with TyC Sports reporting that he 'dreams' of playing for the La Liga giants. Madrid are looking to deploy a similar strategy that saw them sign Cristiano Ronaldo, who is Garnacho's personal idol.

Garnacho's recent performances have not only impressed rival teams. Former Arsenal star Ian Wright believes the United winger is quickly becoming a major issue when opposition managers draw up their game plans.
"I need to mention Garnacho because he is a massive problem for everybody. In spells and in moments during that game he was doing some unbelievable things," he told the Ringer FC podcast.

"I thought it was a very impressive performance in a massive game for him, especially considering his age. As soon as they get the structure right around him he can start to learn more and know where he needs to be in a game. At the moment it’s so chaotic in there. But if that happens then we’re really going to see the best of him, we really are."

Garnacho also has a fan in national team boss Lionel Scaloni, who has dropped a heavy hint the United star should expect a Copa America call-up. But Scaloni also fired a warning that no-one in his team can get complacent.

“Alejandro Garnacho and Facundo Buonanotte are here because they are considered to be in the Copa América. We are all strong and eager to continue. The most important thing was to strengthen and let the team know what we want from them," he said.

"We are clear about the path to follow. It is not easy to compete again after winning everything. We are continually evolving and trying to get the best to play. There are many players and the final choice is never easy."

headline: Harry Maguire risks Sir Jim Ratcliffe's wrath with honest Gareth Southgate admission
body: Harry Maguire has called on Gareth Southgate to remain in his post with England beyond Euro 2024 after the Three Lions chief emerged as a top target for Manchester United
Harry Maguire wants Gareth Southgate to stay on as England manager beyond this summer's European Championships despite interest in his services from Manchester United.

Southgate, 53, has transformed the fortunes of the national team since Sam Allardyce's departure almost eight years ago. He has guided the Three Lions to a World Cup semi-final and came within a whisker of glory at Euro 2020, losing the final on penalties.

The Star revealed earlier this week that Ineos, led by new Manchester United part-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe, have identified Southgate as their No.1 target to replace Erik ten Hag if a managerial change is made this summer. The Dutchman remains under pressure and his long-term future at the club now Ratcliffe and co are in charge of sporting operations is far from certain.

Maguire, who has been in integral part of the England squad under Southgate for years, would surely benefit should he take the top job at Old Trafford - but he's backed the Three Lions chief to stay on beyond Euro 2024.

When he was asked if he wanted Southgate to remain in his post-long-term, Maguire said: "Yeah, definitely, obviously.‌ We want to be successful in the Euros – we are not looking at the World Cup at the moment – but obviously, if we are successful at the Euros, which is our main focus, of course, we want to be successful.

“If Gareth’s the man to make us be successful then we want him to stay as long as possible. I’ve had a great relationship with him. I’ve been a big part of the success ad the progression that we’ve shown as a country. And I’m sure he will say the same thing now, it’s all about winning a trophy.

‌“I don’t know what’s going to happen after the Euros, I don’t know if he knows what’s going to happen. But I feel like what he’s done from when he first took over this job to where we are at now, we’ve taken huge strides and he’s a massive part of that.”
While Maguire may be keen for Southgate to stay with England, his comments are unlikely to prevent Ratcliffe and Ineos from making a move for their top target.

Southgate's contract with the Football Association expires in December and he has so far refused to entertain discussions over an extension. It's been outlined that prising him away from his current contract would not be an overly expensive process for Manchester United.

Much will hinge on how United end the season, as well as England's performance at Euro 2024. Failure to qualify for next season's Champions League could lead to Ten Hag leaving the club - particularly if Southgate is open to moving on from England.

headline: England dressing room's opinion on Gareth Southgate amid Man Utd manager job links
body: Harry Maguire says the whole England squad are desperate for Gareth Southgate to stay on and lead them into the 2026 World Cup but accepts they have to deliver a trophy
Harry Maguire has revealed England's players are desperate to win the Euros this summer - to convince Gareth Southgate to stay on as manager.
Southgate's contract as England boss expires in December while he is also on Manchester United's wish list to be their next manager.
But Maguire says the whole England squad are desperate for Southgate to stay on and lead them into the 2026 World Cup but accepts they have to deliver a trophy this summer.

England will go to the Euros as one of the favourites and Southgate has put discussions about his own future on hold until after the tournament.‌ When asked whether the players want him to stay on, United defender Maguire said: “Yeah, definitely, obviously.‌

“We want to be successful in the Euros – we are not looking at the World Cup at the moment – but obviously if we are successful at the Euros, which is our main focus, of course, we want to be successful.

“If Gareth’s the man to make us be successful then we want him to stay as long as possible. I’ve had a great relationship with him. I’ve been a big part of the success ad the progression that we’ve shown as a country. And I’m sure he will say the same thing now, it’s all about winning a trophy.

‌Maguire also says the players talk all the time about what it would feel like to win a trophy, having gone so close under Southgate as they were semi-finalists in the 2018 World Cup, reached the Euros final and lost to France in the quarter-finals in Qatar in 2022.
‌Maguire added: “We’ve been so close. I feel as a group we’re ready to win. If you asked every single player in the squad they’d say the expectation is to win the tournament.

‌“However, we do understand that it’s tournament football and if we are going to win the Euros, you are probably going to have to win a penalty shoot-out, so you are going to have to be prepared on that aspect.

headline: Man Utd news: Gareth Southgate gets next boss backing as Roy Keane reignites feud
body: Manchester United are eyeing England boss Gareth Southgate as their next manager with a replacement for Casemiro also identified at another Premier League club
Manchester United's focus continues to be on what the club will look like from next season.

Erik ten Hag is attempting to land a spot in next season's Champions League and bag a trophy, but whether he'll be in the dugout next season remains to be seen. Sir Jim Ratcliffe has already begun bringing in people off the pitch and is potentially drawing up a list of managerial candidates.

United have been unable to build on last season's promise with the team continuing to be inconsistent. Sunday's FA Cup win over Liverpool was a high point of the season as the club continue to plan for the future. Here's the latest from Old Trafford.
Gary Neville and Roy Keane both believe Gareth Southgate would be a solid candidate to become the next United boss as questions continue to hang over the future of Ten Hag.

Ratcliffe could yet opt for a change in the dugout and he's also looking to bring in Dan Ashworth, who has a relationship with Southgate following their time with England. The Three Lions boss is yet to commit to the national team beyond the Euros this summer.

Keane said: "His connection with Dan Ashworth, who he has worked with previously. Yeah, I’m not that surprised with it (the links).” Neville claimed: "I never saw Gareth Southgate as a Manchester United manager, psychologically, I never saw that. I can see it now."

Keane took a swipe at Sir Alex Ferguson after it was claimed the former United boss used to pull his players out of international duty towards the end of the season. The former skipper has not spoken to Ferguson since he was forced out of Old Trafford in 2005 after a bitter fall-out.

Neville claimed the ex-United boss used to withdraw his players from England friendlies during the title run-in. Responding to Neville's claim, Keane said he would be “ashamed” to tell players they were not allowed to represent their country.

“When I was a manager, and obviously players were getting called up, I’d be ashamed of my life to tell a player that he couldn’t go and play for his country,” he said. “You might say it’s a different challenge at Manchester United, but I still think you’re a manager and when a player gets an international call up, you should be happy for them because it’s a dream."

The Red Devils are weighing up a move for Wolves midfielder Joao Gomes – who could make his Brazil debut against England. United are looking to sign a holding midfielder this summer - with Casemiro likely to leave – and have identified £40million-rated Gomes as a potential replacement for his fellow Brazilian.
Gomes has been watched by United on several occasions this season, most recently earlier this month, when Wolves beat Fulham 2-1 at Molineux in the Premier League.

The 23-year-old, signed by Wolves for £12m from Flamengo in January 2023, is expected to be handed his first cap for Brazil against Gareth Southgate's side at Wembley on Saturday. Gomes, a combative central midfielder nicknamed 'The Pitbull' in his homeland, has also attracted interest from United's Premier League rivals Tottenham and Newcastle.

headline: Harry Maguire believes Man Utd have found next Jude Bellingham - and he's already at the club
body: England defender Harry Maguire has enjoyed playing big brother to 18-year-old Kobbie Mainoo at club level for Manchester United and has no doubts that he is ready for his country
Harry Maguire believes England have got another Jude Bellingham on their hands.
England defender Maguire has enjoyed playing big brother to 18-year-old Kobbie Mainoo at club level for Manchester United and has no doubts that he is ready for his country.
There are plenty of pictures with Maguire standing alongside Mainoo after taking the teenage midfielder under his wing and now he believes the teenager is ready to gatecrash the Euros squad.

Mainoo has been a revelation for United after only making his first Premier League start in November but now has the chance of getting on the plane this summer alongside Real Madrid superstar Bellingham.

And Maguire insists Mainoo is ready and will have no fear going into the tournament. "I don't see why not," said Maguire. "To play at a major tournament, obviously, it's big to have experience but also the young boys do come in and sometimes they play with no fear and they can excel in that way.

‌"I don't have any concerns whatsoever. It's incredible he's (only) 18, he's so mature. He's a bit like Jude was when he was a young boy. He's got a mature head on his shoulders. I had no concerns. I see day in, day out his ability in training. He just wants to work hard and do well. I congratulated him, said he deserved it, keep it up, and make sure he enjoys himself.
‌"He's got everything, he can handle the ball brilliantly. He's really strong, powerful, and you can see the progression to play that role, especially for Manchester United.

‌"Listen, we have a lot of good centre-mids in this country at the moment, a lot of players who have been there and done it, and shown that they can do it in the big, major tournaments. He'll keep working hard, I'm sure he will, because he's a great lad. It's exciting times for him and his family. We will see where it goes."

It would not be the first time that a prodigious talent has broken through ahead of a tournament as Marcus Rashford did the same when he was a teenager at United ahead of the Euros in 2026.
Incredibly, Rashford is now one of the senior figures who, along with Maguire, are trying to help guide Mainoo through and they regard it as a key part of their own responsibilities at Old Trafford.
Maguire said: "I told him if he needs anything just to ask me, give me a text, about anything, schedule, he thoroughly deserves it. He has been excellent for us this season.‌

"A role and responsibility for the senior players at Manchester United is to bring through academy players. The club is always built on giving opportunities to young boys, we have numerous of them training with us a lot, we try and make them feel welcome.

"And that's a big role and responsibility of the senior players, and we have done that to Kobbie. It's important he feels welcome, he feels comfortable, even coming into this group with England it is really important he feels welcome."

Maguire admits that United should be in better shape than they currently are and his own season has been disrupted by injuries. But Maguire admitted the "crazy" FA Cup tie with Liverpool and the dramatic victory in extra time might be a catalyst to get their season going again, especially with the chance to win silverware.‌

He added: "It's obviously been a difficult season for us. The points tally in the Premier League is not too bad, but it should be a lot better. The five teams above us have accumulated more, a lot to be honest at this stage of the season.
"Obviously we've had a lot of injuries, but so have other clubs, to get knocked out of the Carabao Cup was disappointing and the Champions League campaign was also disappointing.

"We played well in the Champions League Group games, but two red cards have probably cost us from going through there. So to have a good run in the FA Cup is important and it's a huge result for us, to keep that faith that we've still got a chance to go and win something this season.
"The atmosphere was incredible on Sunday and it was really important to give the fans something they deserved, to go home and cheer about. And smile about."

headline: Harry Maguire's mocking response says it all after Conservatives use image without permission
body: The Conservatives used a famous image of Harry Maguire from the 2018 World Cup to promote Rishi Sunak, but the Manchester United star has insisted he did not give them permission to do so
England defender Harry Maguire has revealed the Conservative Party did not ask his permission to use a picture of him in a social media campaign.
The Tories used the now infamous picture of Maguire leaning over a barrier to talk to his then girlfriend Fern with the caption: “Rishi said any League with me in it would be Super anyways.”
It was posted after the Government brought the Football Governance Bill to Parliament with details about how an independent regulator would stop any future European Super League.
Maguire said: “No, they have had no permission. I didn't even know about the advert to be honest.” When asked whether he could do a better job running the country, Maguire laughed: “No comment!”

Manchester United defender Maguire became a national hero during the pandemic when he rallied players to help raise funds to help key workers, including the NHS workers. That was all done despite former Health Minister Matt Hancock claiming footballers should “play their part” by taking a pay cut.
The reality was that Maguire and England team mate Jordan Henderson launched a players’ campaign with the Professional Footballers’ Association to help raise funds and donate huge sums of cash.

Maguire also insists that playing for England means “absolutely everything” as he approaches another tournament.He also paid tribute to Gareth Southgate for sticking by him even when he has been out of the team at club level.

He said: “I think that the faith and the trust that he has shown me throughout my time for England has been brilliant. I think I've been in every single squad I've been available for, I've played every competitive game that I've been available for.
“So it gives me great confidence and belief that I can turn things around. It gave me the belief in myself and he has been a hue part of that and I can only thank him for the support.
“Playing for my country means absolutely everything to me. So if I weren't picked for a squad I'd have been gutted not to turn up and see the lads.”

headline: Rasmus Hojlund agreement reached as Man Utd monitor star's fitness on Denmark duty
body: Rasmus Hojlund has only just returned from injury for Manchester United and was given a place in the Denmark squad but a plan has been put in place to avoid another problem
Denmark have struck an agreement with Manchester United to limit Rasmus Hojlund's game time, boss Kasper Hjulmand has confirmed.
The striker only returned for the Red Devils during last weekend’s FA Cup victory against Liverpool at Old Trafford. He had been suffering with a muscle injury before starting against the Reds.
Hojlund, 21, was taken off after 70 minutes. Despite his recent absence, the striker was still handed a place in the Denmark squad for upcoming friendlies against Switzerland and the Faroe Islands.

Ahead of those games, boss Hjulmand has confirmed that an agreement has been reached with the Red Devils to limit Hojlund’s minutes in an effort to avoid any further injuries. Quoted by Metro, he said: "We have an agreement with United about the total amount of playing time in the two matches.
“He plays from the start against Switzerland and there are no restrictions on how much he can play in that match. Then we'll see what happens after that match.
"Our staff has put together a plan with Erik ten Hag on how he will get the best build-up after Rasmus' injury period. It is both for our good and their good.
"It does not make sense to smash a player through and increase the risk of an injury that goes beyond our own Euro plans. That plan is there for Rasmus and for all other players."

Hojlund was in electric form for Man United ahead of his injury blow. He had found the net in each of his previous six Premier League appearances - his record now sitting at 13 goals in all competitions for the Red Devils following a slow start to life at Old Trafford.
Hojlund will now be aiming to extend his stunning international record. Ahead of Saturday’s clash with Switzerland in Copenhagen, he can boast seven goals in just ten caps since his debut in 2022.

Away from his injury concerns, Hojlund has been caught up in controversy on international duty. It was claimed that his Red Devils teammates were left questioning him for agreeing to an interview with a Man United fan channel.

But he has confirmed that is untrue. Speaking to Danish outlet Tipsbladet, the striker said: "I haven't been told anything, so it's fake news. I haven't read anything about it, but it's definitely not true that I have been told that I can't do an interview with one fan media or another."

headline: Man Utd 'make Mason Greenwood transfer decision' after Sir Jim Ratcliffe hinted at return
body: Mason Greenwood is unlikely to embark on a second loan spell with Getafe next season as Manchester United mull over whether to cash in on the academy graduate in the summer
Mason Greenwood is unlikely to stay at Getafe next season, with Manchester United reportedly not interested in another loan spell.

The 22-year-old has spent the current campaign on loan with the La Liga outfit and has bagged eight goals so far. The spell in Spain came after charges against Greenwood of attempted rape, controlling and coercive behaviour, and assault were dropped by the Crown Prosecution Service in February of 2023.

Those at the top of the Getafe hierarchy are reportedly keen on keeping hold of Greenwood for another season but are unlikely to be able to afford to purchase the England international outright. Unfortunately for them, the Red Devils have decided they want a fee for the striker if they are going to part ways, according to The Sun.

United's new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is yet to make a decision on what to do with Greenwood and has not ruled out the idea of reintegrating the academy graduate back into the first-team fold at Old Trafford.

Ratcliffe said last month: "We will make a decision, correct. All I can do is talk about the principle of how we will approach decisions like that. Is he the right type of footballer, are we happy with if is he a good person or not?

"He's a Manchester United footballer, so we are in charge of football. So the answer is 'Yeah, we have to make decisions. It's quite clear we have to make a decision. There is no decision that's been made. He's on-loan obviously, but he's not the only one.

"We've got one or two footballers that we have to deal with and we have to make a decision on so we will do that. The process will be: understand the facts, not the hype. Then try and come to a fair decision on the basis of values, which is basically is he a good guy or not? Could he play sincerely for Manchester United well, would we be comfortable with it and would the fans be comfortable with it?"

Ratcliffe isn't the only one who has discussed Greenwood, with England boss Gareth Southgate also fielding questions on the 22-year-old. Asked if the forward could add to his tally of one Three Lions cap, the manager explained: "I don't think it's something for pre-Euros.
"Allowing him to get his career going again abroad appears to have been a good move. But I have to say I have not tracked it closely."
Greenwood is contracted to United until the summer of 2025. That same deal includes an option to extend for a further year, though at this stage that seems increasingly unlikely.

headline: Nikita Parris calls on Man Utd to 'step up and grow' before Manchester derby
body: Manchester City host Manchester United at the Etihad Stadium on Saturday in the Women's Super League with Marc Skinner's side 12 points adrift of the league leaders
England forward Nikita Parris said Manchester United need to "step up and grow" as they lag 12 points adrift of their title-chasing Mancunian neighbours.

Despite finishing runners-up in an astounding Women's Super League campaign last season and pushing reigning league champions Chelsea to the brink in both the league and FA Cup, Marc Skinner's side have toiled in a mercurial season.

Indeed, having tumbled out of an inaugural Champions League campaign early, United sit in fourth, 12 points adrift of Manchester City and Chelsea at the top of the table and level on points with Liverpool.
On Saturday, United have a chance to avenge part of their season with a trip away to City at the Etihad Stadium. Victory could keep them within contention for a European spot.

And Parris, 30, has called on her teammates to "step up" to the occasion as they did so often last season. "As a team, we need to step up and grow," Parris told BBC Sport. "All our games have been competitive but in big moments we've lacked experience and it's cost us."

Last season, United claimed four out of a possible six points when confronting City but in another visual of this season's changed fortunes, City not only dispatched United comfortably 3-1 at Old Trafford but also defeated them in the League Cup in a season.

Gareth Taylor's side have been ruthless as they bid to upset Chelsea's quadruple pursuit as part of manager Emma Hayes' goodbye tour. Since defeating United 3-1 in November, City have relished a nine-game winning streak in the WSL, a consistency which has evaded United this season.
"We were competing last year. This year we haven't maintained those high standards," said Parris. "That's where we need to push forward as a team. It won't happen overnight but that's our aim.

"We're definitely not where we want to be. The reality is we need points to go on our side and games out of our control to go our way. We have to take care of business and, in all honesty, we haven't, especially in the big games." Manchester City host Manchester United at 12:30 on Saturday at the Etihad Stadium.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund lifts lid on Benni McCarthy meeting that improved his goalscoring form
body: Rasmus Hojlund has been in excellent form so far this year and the Manchester United striker has praised the work of coach Benni McCarthy and his forwards meetings
Rasmus Hojlund has credited 'forwards meetings' led by coach Benni McCarthy for his improved form in 2024.

After making the move to Old Trafford from Atalanta last summer, Hojlund initially struggled to make much of an impact and it took until Boxing Day for the 21-year-old to score his first Premier League goal.
However, Hojlund has scored six league goals in five games in 2024 and when asked what changed to trigger his turnaround in form, the striker highlighted McCarthy's work with United's forwards.
"You could say that we have found each other better," he told Danish outlet BT. "We have had some forwards meetings with Benni McCarthy, where we talked about things.

"It wasn't just me and two others, it was everyone from the front line who attended the meeting. We talked about playing each other [in] well and helping each other, because that's the way we will get the best results.

"We saw some video clips, and then there was reference to the fact that, here and there, some things should be done better. We could see that and then we have carried it out on the field, in training and matches.

"I try to train well and prepare every single day. I train on both my strengths and weakness. I have got better and better. I have had a good month [or so] but it has been the result of good work over a long period. It clicks a little better than at the start of the Premier League season."

Marcus Rashford has also credited McCarthy with helping him improve as a goalscorer after he netted 30 times for United last season. "He's definitely helped me a lot. To have attack-minded coaches is good for us. He's always there speaking to us about these things," Rashford said.

However, the former Blackburn and West Ham striker recently admitted he wants to get back into management at some point in the future, having previously had spells in charge of South African clubs Cape Town City and AmaZulu.

"With the knowledge I’ve gained and everything I've contributed to the team – I want to take that and then eventually become a manager," he told YOU Magazine. "Because once you've sat in the hot seat at a club and you've experienced the adrenaline of decision-making and leading, you want to experience that again one day."

headline: Joao Gomes has already expressed Liverpool transfer hopes as Man Utd plot £40m bid
body: Wolves midfielder Joao Gomes has emerged as a potential summer transfer target for Manchester United, but the Brazilian has previously teased an interest in playing for Liverpool
Joao Gomes is on Manchester United's summer wishlist - but has previously expressed a desire to play for Liverpool.

Gomes, 23, has made a strong impression at Wolves since joining the club from Flamengo in January 2023 for just £12million and Mirror Footballrevealed on Thursday morning that his imperious performances at Molineux have piqued the attention of Ineos.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe and his team have taken charge of sporting operations at Old Trafford and are in the market for a new midfielder in the summer with Casemiro, 32, likely to depart. Ratcliffe's preference is to acquire up-and-coming talent rather than blockbuster names and Gomes, who United believe could be available for £40million, fits the bill as a player with significant resale value.

United have watched the talented midfielder on several occasions this season and could firm up their interest in Gomes in the coming months. However, Gomes' previous comments on playing for United's arch-rivals may not go down too well.

Speaking in a media interview back in the summer of 2022, Gomes said: “Liverpool are a team I would [like to] play for. Playing in the Champions League is my biggest dream and that of my family, my biggest dream in football.”

Gomes has not only caught the eye of United since adapting seamlessly to life in the Premier League. Both Newcastle and Tottenham have also had him watched ahead of the summer, for a player whom Wolves don't want to lose, but accept could go if the price is right.

The Brazilian, nicknamed 'the pitbull' has adapted seamlessly to life in the Premier League, shining at the heart of the Black Country club's midfield - filling the void left by Ruben Neves last summer - and is poised to win his first senior cap for his country against England this weekend.

Despite impressing last year after joining the club for an initial £60m from Real Madrid, Casemiro has failed to live up to expectations this season and United would welcome the opportunity to get his significant salary off the books.

And with Ratcliffe and Ineos determined to move away from over-inflated transfer fees and salaries, Casemiro and a host of other high-earning, underperforming players including Antony and Raphael Varane, will be up for grabs at the end of the season.
As well as Gomes, Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite is also a key summer target for Manchester United following his impressive performances for the Toffees this year.

headline: Loving Casemiro and rejecting Man City - the inside story of Kobbie Mainoo's journey at Manchester United
body: Kobbie Mainoo is training with England during the international break and his rise at Man United has been a joy to follow.
When Manchester United and Real Madrid played each other in pre-season last summer, a fan posted photos of Jude Bellingham and Kobbie Mainoo on social media.
The caption read: "Bellingham and England's best midfielder."
The post was intended as a joke, but there's an outside chance that Mainoo could start alongside the Real Madrid star at this summer's European Championship in Germany.

Bellingham and Declan Rice are guaranteed to start and Mainoo would perfectly complement that pair as the No.8, but it would be a remarkable achievement for him to be included in the England squad, never mind to be given a prominent role in the team by Gareth Southgate.
Mainoo has been exceptional for United this season and his performances haven't come as a surprise to those who know him best - they were confident he would succeed.
The MEN exclusively revealed in July that Mainoo was set to be kept around the first team and that preceded him becoming the breakout star of the pre-season tour.
Mainoo was brilliant in friendlies against Lyon, Leeds and Arsenal, and his breakthrough into the team was only delayed by the ankle injury he sustained against Real Madrid.
The club carefully handled his return in October and he made a handful of appearances for the Under-21s to get back up to speed, with the words 'eased back into action' used.
Mainoo's performance against Salford was impressive and the MEN's match report read: "The midfielder has outgrown academy football and his talent is needed in the first team."
Erik ten Hag played Mainoo in successive away games against Everton, Newcastle and Galatasaray and he performed like someone with over 300 senior appearances.

Mainoo's composure is remarkable and if he was any more laidback, he'd probably be horizontal. That trait struck coaches from an early age and the anecdote from when Mainoo trained with the first team for the first time at Carrington encapsulates his personality.

That's because when Mainoo took part in his first training session with the first team, he nonchalantly told a coach 'it was alright' and that he 'did OK'. It's understood two senior players subsequently told that coach he'd actually made a strong impression and held his own.
That is typical of his character and his family, who have a Ghanaian background, help to keep him grounded. Mainoo has the right people around him and still lives with his mother.
United sources have said they would be surprised if Mainoo ever got ahead of himself and he's been described as a very calm character who takes everything in his stride.
A source also described him as 'a real natural talent with high technical ability' and everyone who knows the player paints a picture of a grounded, likeable young man.
There have been dozens of players to come through United's academy who have gone by the wayside due to mentality concerns, but such doubts have never existed with Mainoo.
He has the required temperament to enjoy a brilliant career, and his ability was identifiable when he was just five years old, as his former coach explained in January 2023.
"In terms of my time at Cheadle and Gatley, he was definitely a standout player by a mile at that young age," Steve Vare, who is still involved with the Stockport club, told the MEN.
"It was all a bit too easy and I was trying to make it more difficult to test him. His dad asked whether he would be pushed up into some of the teams, a couple of ages ahead of himself."
But before joining United's academy aged nine, Mainoo's father, Felix, searched for a team that was good enough to challenge him and somewhere he could play up an age group.
Mainoo joined Failsworth Dynamos and he was coached by Ian Kelly, who also spoke to the MEN last year after the youngster made his United debut against Charlton Athletic.
"I'd play Kobbie on the wing or in midfield," he said. "The lad I had up front scored most of the goals but Kobbie chipped in a lot. He was quick, so he was really good on the wing.
"But if you did put him in the middle, he could shoot and move the ball forward. We'd always win the league, we played for cups and we'd win those, we won 'the treble' in his last season.
"There was one team visit to a tournament in Blackpool when we stayed over and I had a drink with Kobbie's dad, who is a really good bloke. He's a funny guy and we had a real laugh.

"We won that tournament and beat an academy side in the final. We also went down to Manchester City, a scout wanted us to play their team, and we only got beat by a goal. The scout said we've never had a team that's come here and given them a game."
Mainoo went to both United and City's academies when he was a child and in another world, he's just broken into the starting team at the Etihad under Pep Guardiola.
Fortunately for United, Mainoo chose to join their academy and although City have attempted to lure him away when it would have been possible, he's chosen to stay each time.
A report emerged in November suggesting City were planning to make a move for Mainoo, but United were relaxed because their admiration of the player isn't anything new.
Something disastrous would have to happen for Mainoo to defect from red to blue and he's got the potential to be a player United build their midfield around for the next 10 years.
Mainoo has started 11 of United's 12 games across all competitions in 2024 and his Instagram followers practically doubled when he scored the winning goal in the 4-3 win over Wolves.
He conducted his first external media duties after that victory at Molineux Stadium and when he returned to the dressing room, he received a loud ovation from his teammates.
Just a few weeks before that game, Mainoo had been shopping - he enjoys fashion - in Manchester and he modestly remarked that nobody in the city would recognise him.

Although that was unlikely to be true at the time, it's certainly not true now. Mainoo is already adored by United fans and he recently pulled over in his car, despite being at the start of a roundabout, to sign autographs for young fans who had waved him down.

Additionally, he made a heartwarming gesture when inviting a supporter and his son to Old Trafford, following the loss of a family member, whose last game watching United before passing away was against Wolves when he scored the late match-winning goal.

Those small gestures show that Mainoo 'gets it' and it's why he's quickly become a fan favourite. There's no feeling like watching a player from United's academy perform on the biggest stage and he's equally admired among his peers, who have been taken by his talent, at the club.
Casemiro has said United could have 'a top player for years', Bruno Fernandes has said 'he's got so much quality' and Rasmus Hojlund has described him as a 'generational talent'.
A source also told the MEN that Mainoo 'loves to play with Casemiro' because the Brazilian's defensive discipline gives him the licence to take up more advanced positions.
Mainoo's long-term future will lie in the No.8 midfield role and he's enjoyed working alongside the 32-year-old, who has given him advice and pointers during training sessions.
Although the Stockport-born lad signed a long-term contract in February 2023, it's understood initial discussions have taken place over a new deal to reflect his growing importance.

Naturally, he will receive a wage increase if he signs a new deal, but the MEN understands that all parties are relaxed about the situation and there is no rush to accelerate talks, with the player keen to focus on his United performances for the remainder of the season.
The performance-related bonuses in Mainoo's current contract have been triggered, which is why there is no panic from the player's camp to urgently push for a new deal.

Mainoo has made headlines again this week after he was promoted to the senior England squad. He was initially supposed to spend the international break with the Three Lions' Under-21s and his call-up came as a surprise because Gareth Southgate didn't contact him after the Liverpool game.
The surprise made the promotion an even sweeter moment to savour and Mainoo couldn't wipe the smile from his face when speaking to England's in-house media team.
The player had been weighing up his options about whether to represent England or Ghana and he is proud of his family roots, but he's been advised to lean toward the Three Lions.
England are set to play Brazil and Belgium in international friendlies across the next few days and Mainoo receiving a cameo in either game would represent yet another milestone.
Just over 18 months ago, someone close to Mainoo boldly predicted it was a matter of when, not if, he would play for England and that confidence was not misplaced.
Mainoo seems to be the real deal and he's a Red through and through.
